bibl.idno: The Papers of Henry Rose Carter [manuscript] ; HEALTHSCI MS-10.

div1.p: Carter makes notes about Henry Rose Carter's theory of extrinsic incubation and Wade Hampton Frost's editing work on the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter fragment from [Laura Armistead Carter], [July 10, 1926]
div1.p:
Repeat question
3= If a ship from W. Africa
or Mexico took (a) infected
steg-aboard (b) (or men with
Y. F. [unclear] from whom
non-infected steg. breeding aboard in the water cases could could
become infected; the
crew wld probably
there wld. probably be an
epidemic among the
crew who wld. either die
or recover in a com-
paratively short time.
The infected mosquitoes
however, wld. live in-
definitely. This time, of
course being longer
for (b) as you wld have to
add the period of extrinsic
incubation before the
welluninfected members of the
crew developed y f--.
A ship then cld. be infective
at her port of arrival
a long time after leaving
her port of departure.

When is your history
to be published? If you
are not pressing it-
Father's book should go
to press in the near
future and Mr Sherell
while it does not
go into matters Virginian
re Y. F. epidemics in Va. I
think you will be glad to
have read it before taking
that particular phase of
your subject.

I am profoundly thank-
ful to say that the final
editing is being done by
Dr. W. H. F. if the I. H.
C. of Hygiene, whom
Father considered the
foremost Epidemiologist
in the Americas. = Ø

Frost will be in London
for the next month,
but will resume the
final editing of F's
book (2/5 already done)
about Aug. 1st.
With very best wishes
to yourself & Dr. Williams
I [unclear] wishing that
I could answer all of
your questions in
